Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned basic skills in R and important concepts in statistics, along with ways to apply these to real-life cases and data.
I learned basic coding techniques in R. I also expanded upon my existing stats knowledge and learned about statistical analysis methods such as logistic regression, ANOVA, ANCOVA etc.
Learned lots of R
I learned a lot about R and truly did learn how to code

Practical programming skill skills in R for data analysis and various statistical methods including: data cleaning, web data scarping, boxplot, histogram , scatterplot, t-test, correlation, bootstrap, permutation test, multiple regression, ANOVA/ANCOVA, generalized linear model, logistic regression, and multinomial regression.
How to use R and how to interpret the output of the data analysis
Intro to R, which is useful. A review and expansion on basic statistics.
I learned a basic understanding of R, which is a nice coding language to know. It's applicable in the real world and very practical.

This course was my first exposure to any coding, and I think that JDRS goes above and beyond to make sure that the material is accessible to all. I learned how to begin utilizing R, how to scrape data off of webpages, and how to answer data analysis questions using statistical tools. Further, I also obtained some experience with data visualization throughout this course.
Pretty much anything you'll need to know regarding the basics of data analysis in R.
A variety of statistical coding techniques in R.
Data analysis and visualization with R, as well as general knowledge of biostatistics
Learned how to use R and how to use many statistical methods.
Having never coded before, I learned a lot about how to use R and just think in terms of a programmer. I also learned a couple statistical techniques like permutation tests and bootstrapping.
Working knowledge of statistical techniques and R
I learned how to use the knowledge of statistics I learned in previous S&DS courses in R, as well as other new usefull skills like web data scraping.
I learned R but not much stats.
How to use R, data analysis skills.
An overview of statistical analysis techniques and a gentle introduction to coding in R.
Basics of R, review of statistical procedures and when/how to use them.
Learned how to think and code in R, albeit quite basically. Rehashed some statistical concepts.
How to use R to get data, clean data, and conduct basic regression and tests

I went into the class knowing very little R programming and came out feeling confident about my R programming abilities. It should be noted that this class will not transform you into a master R programmer. However, I learned a lot and its a great way to build a foundation for your R programming skills.
Data Science & Exploration!
Stat 230 is a great intro to R! It is accessible and cool to know how to code. I got so much out of this course!!!
We learned a lot of statistical tests along with the theory behind them. We also learned how to program in R, which is a super useful skill.
Understanding of R and data analysis.
I learned to code.

This class is a great introduction to how to use R. It is straightforward and simple -- you learn things that you would feasibly need to do for a research project. Cleaning data, web scraping, running different linear models are all important facets of the course. JDRS condenses material that may seem mathematically inaccessible to students to R functions that output clear visuals. This does have its downsides though. Some students may be interested in learning more about WHY something works rather than that it just does. This class does not build in time to address the background information, so be cognizant of that as you move along the course.
I further advanced my knowledge of S&DS and expanding my knowledge of R programming.
I learned R, which will be a very useful tool for data analysis for me going forward.
A lot of R coding skills.
I learned how to code R and learned advanced statistical techniques.
Learned how to use R and data scrape from a website and clean data
I learned a lot about the topic of statistics.

We learnt a broad overview of the use of R for statistical work, starting with basic syntax and ultimately covering graphical representations, a variety of tests, statistics, regressions and models; data cleaning, web scraping and interpretation of data.
Basic understanding to R language, a review to Intro Stats and more complex stats knowledge, and how to utilize R to help analyze data sets.
Data analysis
coding in R; different statistical tests and when to use them; linear, multiple, logistic regression; web/data scraping
I learned how to use statistical tests in R, to produce expected content from directions given on R.
I learned lots about coding R, conducting statistical tests, and analyzing data. I feel like I came out of this course proficient in R and in my basic stats skills.
How to use a lot of statistic principles from AP Statistics and apply them computationally on large datasets.

I learned an extensive amount of knowledge on statistics (tests, concepts, interpreting results) and the program R. The course helped me develop an intuition for object-oriented coding, including data cleaning, data selection, code notations and functions. Above all this course made me excited to understand R and statistics and analyze data with a bit more comfort due to the enthusiasm brought by the instructor.

I learned how to code in R by learning specific R commands, but also how to teach myself how to learn and figure out what code means, and how to use code to get what I want in R. 
I also learned more about data analysis and exploration methods, and how to conduct my own experiments and analysis with datasets in statistics.

I learned a lot about how to clean and analyze data through tests including t tests, permutation tests, boostraps, anovas, and generalized linear models. This is not the course if you want an overview of statistics. However, it is good for learning to look at data and learning to use R, which will probably be important skills in the future for any researcher in the natural sciences, economics major, and more. The data we looked at as well as the conclusions we drew from analyses were also really interesting and made psets more fun.

coding in R
applying some statistics concepts to analyze real world data

I gained an introduction into how to code in R and basic data analysis using various statistical tests like t-tests, permutation tests, bootstrap confidence interval generation, and various types of ANOVAs.
I learned how to use R to conduct various statistical tests, such as t-tests, one-way and two-way ANOVA, multivariable regression, GLM, permutation tests, bootstrapped confidence intervals.
I feel really comfortable using R and coding.  I didn't know anything going into the course, and now I feel very competent in this language.
I learned to use R.
Decent R coding skills
I learned to use R!
How to use R, doing AP Stats stuff in R
Basic R skills. Enough to learn and branch out to use R effectively

I learned how to use R! This should be very useful for research. I also learned lots of new techniques that I had never seen before in AP Statistics, like the bootstrap, permutation tests for significance, generalized linear models, and logistic/multinomial regression. There wasn't a lot of statistical theory in this class (this class is mainly about practical statistics, rather than theoretical), but there was much more than I expected given the reviews for the course, which was great because theory is important. The final project where we got to analyze our own data was great for putting what I learned into practice.
how to code in R
I gained a firm understanding of R and the various statistical tests I can perform with it.
Using R to analyze data!
T tests, permutation tests, bootstrapping, generally how to clean data and use R.
Good R skills, and data analysis
I learned how to code in R and I got a better grasp of many statistical techniques that I first learned in S&DS 100.
Basic coding for in R and building upon intro stats concepts.
Basic R, good refresher of intro statistics
Learnt how to use r, run basic statistical analyses and to select and present a data analysis study.
I really felt like I got a high-level overview of R  and I got a lot of support while doing it. I highly recommend the class.
Basic statistical skills in R
Web Scraping, a basic understanding of R, and creating and explaining graphs.
Advanced statistics in R (by advanced, I mean that it was advanced to me). A great class.

So much! Recap of basic stats and introduction to additional methods of statistical analysis. Great foundation in understanding how to use R for analyzing data; including cleaning of data, usual statistical techniques, and web scraping.
Reinforced knowledge of basic statistics; good grounding in using R for statistical analysis, creating visualizations, data cleaning, and scraping data from websites.

I now know how to perform basic statistical analyses on datasets using R. We learned basic data structure, confidence tests, ANOVA, ANCOVA, Generalized Linear Model, bootstrapping and permutation, and a teeny-tiny bit of web scraping.
Using R to conduct data exploration and analysis -- i would say now i have an idea as to try to do (and why) when i'm given a data set, which is an invaluable skill in almost any field
I learned how to code in R. This was perhaps the best practical thing I've learned so far at Yale.

A good class to take after high school AP Stats or equivalent non-R course. The class was thorough in explaining how to use R to perform previously learned skills, and, while it didn't spend time explaining how to do a t-test  or what that meant, did link to PDFs explaining into Stats for anyone who is coming into this class after a long break from stats. Very little explanation about coding, so good if you have previous coding experience but perhaps a big of a sharp jump for someone with no coding experience.
I learned how analyze a dataset using numerous tools such as plots and histograms, t-tests and permutation tests, Anova tests, regression and more.
From this course, I learned more about Data Analysis than I had in two semesters of econometrics. You learn everything you need to know to make a start in the world of analyzing data.
Better knowledge of R.
How to code in R! Super helpful introduction to R from ground up, with some statistics mixed in. A lot more practical (i.e. how to run this test and interpret results) than theoretical statistics.
Learned so much about data visualization in R, completely starting from scratch!
How to use R in order to do statistical analysis
I learned the basics of analyzing data in R by creating graphs, running regressions etc. I had never coded before so I also learned a lot about coding in general through taking this course.
Coding in R, making statistical models in R,etc.
How to code in R
A great overview of statistics
Basic skills of programming in R, data scraping, and interpretation of data.
just like the title, data exploration and analysis

I've never done coding before, and I thought this was a fantastic intro to it. I've been interested in stats applications (sports, surveys, betting, etc.) for a while now, and it's cool to be introduced to a tool (R) that can facilitate statistical analysis.
How to use R.
R coding! A strong basis at that
Data analysis and R
I learned how to use R to conduct a series of statistical analyses.
Working knowledge of R, refined data analysis skills
This is really a class in intro stats and how to use R.
Learned how to code in R, some new statistical tests, etc.

I learned the foundations of the statistical language R and how to format code using RMarkdown. I also learned about how to clean data and conduct various statistical analyses on different types of datasets.
I learnt how to work with R and analyse data using a bunch of different techniques, including scraping data from the web and cleaning it.
This course was a very technical course - could accurately be named "Intro to R." I do feel well-prepared to complete a wide array of statistical tasks and analysis in R.

1. very useful R programming skill
2. basic idea of statistics

I learned a lot about how to use the R programming language to analyze data in a variety of ways. We used R to dramatically speed up a lot of the processes that you learn about in an intro statistics course, and we also learned how to visualize data using different types of plots.
Employing concepts from statistics 100, learning to code with R, understanding data cleaning, understanding several different ways to analyze a specific data set
General review of topics I learned in AP Statistics as well as knowledge of how to navigate and utilize R.
Practical usage of R
Learned how to code in R and how to do statistical analysis in R.
Good working knowledge of R.  Better understanding of how to use statistics in realistic contexts.
Data analysis, learning from video lectures, and methods to avoid procrastinating on the video lectures.
strengths -- it was awesome that the lectures were recorded

The format of the course is extremely convenient. Lectures are streamed and are not mandatory, which is a huge plus if you have five classes. There are plenty of resources to supplement learning, included daily office hours and PDF notes. There are no in class exams, so most of your grade consists of psets. JDRS's lectures, although slightly boring at times, are easy to follow. While the problems sets usually assess the content of the lectures in a pretty straightforward manner, I often felt like I was copying and pasting code from JDRS's notes onto my p-sets and only slightly modifying it. Therefore, I would recommend modifying them so they can be more engaging.

Strengths: thorough introduction to R, great professor/TAs
Weaknesses: the problem sets don't really require too much thinking since you can copy and paste most of the material from the slides. should be less focus on R in class and more on the statistics.
The class was amazing-- maybe if it went slower towards the end, that would be beneficial

It was nice that all the lectures were recorded, so not very many people went to class. The class notes in RStudio were very clear and the statistical theory in the slides were very informative. The homeworks and take-home exams basically involved adjusting code that was presented in class, and not much coding from scratch was required. Overall, the course was straightforward, but I still feel that I learned important data analysis tools.
Strengths are that JDRS is a legend and facilitated learning to the max. The weaknesses were that the homeworks were too similar to class topics, so it didnt require much thought
it's much easier to say this looking back on the course, but I wish that there was more opportunity to think creatively instead of just basically copying what JDRS did in class.
I enjoyed the class.

A major strength of this course is the professor, JDRS. His level of organization and method of sharing all course information was integral in helping me to understand the material; I could re-watch lectures I did not fully grasp the first time around, and I could reference the updated pdf of which functions we used in each class. I definitely think that some additional transparency and consistency in the grading by the separate TAs would be an improvement to the course.

The videotaped lectures made it super flexible in learning the material on your own time and also referring back to anything that needed refreshing. The professor's highly comprehensive lecture notes were also extremely helpful in completing assignments and projects. Overall, the course was well set up for learning on one's own time and independently.

This class was far and away the most well organized STEM class I've taken at Yale. My only suggestion is that psets should require a basic understanding of the underlying theory; it is all too possible to get an A on every single pset without intuitively understanding anything.
This course is well organized and I really enjoyed how the lectures are posted on canvas, allowing us greater flexibility with the material.
This is an excellent course. If possible, I should spend more time on this course.

Strengths - the problem sets and lectures taught R very well.
Weaknesses - i didn't feel like there was enough emphasis on the statistical reasons why what we were doing worked - by the end I knew how to do the tests and what the conditions I needed to do statistical tests were, but not as much of an intuitive understanding as to how the tests worked and when to apply them.
I thought that the homework consisted of me basically copying JDRS' code, and while I learned a lot, it would have been easy for me to really take away nothing if I didn't put any effort in.

Strengths: Clear instructions on all assignments.
Weaknesses: Feedback on assignments could be returned faster.
Lecture should be more focused on stats concepts, and students should be left to figure out R on their own in the assignments.
A strength is that all of the lectures are recorded, so you don't have to go to class (in fact, JDRS encouraged this).
Class is recorded, so you can watch from home. Also, I think JDRS gives you all of the resources that you would need to learn R and statistics

Strengths: It's clear how to do well in this class, and the class is well-structured to facilitate student learning.
Weaknesses: A few terrible TA's

This class is great, as someone who knew some statistics but needed a refresher and had never used R before (though did have some coding background). The option to watch videos of classes is extremely helpful and provides flexibility, while JDRS does a good job of reviewing the background to the analyses you'll be using without getting bogged down in the math. This class is very practical, and I already have found it useful for several other projects I've been working on.

Strengths: JDRS is an amazing instructor and it is helpful that he puts videos online
Weaknesses: the structure of the problem sets encourages simply copy and pasting from the class notes rather than actually trying to figure out how to do certain processes ourselves, which I think constrained my ability on the project. But overall amazing course.
Strengths: All the lectures were recorded and uploaded into Canvas

it was a great course. easy to follow, lectures are online, hard at times, but plenty of resources. they could however post grades sooner. as of may 9th of this review, we still don't have exam 2 notes (April 23rd or something)....
Learn how to do data science! Great course :)
The psets are not that much time at all, and are fun to do! This is a great class!! Take it!!! There are no in-class exams!

Online lectures are awesome because you can study for this class whenever you want. JDRS uses Canvas more than any professor (so many helpful resources). Lots of office hours too. They really set you up for doing well in the class.
It's good, a little too in depth in the statistics for what I would have liked.
The course was great.

This class has a full schedule of office hours, and JDRS is readily accessible. If you have questions, there are so many ways to find answers. You need to be willing to reach out if you don't understand something. 

While the online lectures are extremely convenient, they will not be of use to you if you don't watch them. Lectures are useful. Take the time to make the hike up to Kroon or block out an hour and fifteen to listen to JDRS demonstrate the wild west of R to you. He puts in a lot of effort to strip things down to only their significance.

The structure of this class was very organized to the point that the Professor video recorded all the lectures and put them, along with the notes, on Canvas after class. I honestly have no complaints about this class.
Strengths are you really do learn R and psets are the right level of difficulty. I think the only weakness is that the class is long and can get a little boring.
I like that the course was recorded so i could go at my own pace. The psets were the right difficulty and office hours were very helpful
Lectures are recorded so it makes it easy to go back and rewatch lecture and watch it whenever is convenient

Strength: the teacher is very organized and very clear lecturer. Extremely enjoy how he is able to break down topics into things that anyone can understand. Weaknesses: it's very easy to fall behind in the lectures because it is webcasted.

I really enjoyed the way that the class was offered in so many different formats, I felt like it offered everyone a different way to learn and absorb the material. I feel that the grading of the assignments was sometimes a bit unfair, the different TAs seemed to have widely different standards even when following one rubric.

I have many issues with the way this course is taught, but I'll probably just bring them directly to the S&DS department rather than the course evaluation system. Here are just some of them: 1) the psets are too easy, and nobody is actually learning from them. 2) it's too easy to not go to lecture and copy the code from lecture to do the psets. 3) the class should have a greater emphasis on dplyr and ggplot2, rather than discussing them during one lecture towards the end of the course. 4) the class is too focused on how to run models in R, and not enough about how to interpret them. 5) we don't get enough experience actually wrangling large datasets. sure, we discuss how to clean text using gsub (which is a great skill to have, don't get me wrong), but the class does not teach what you should do when you are presented with a 3 million row dataset and you have to find some useful insights out of it (and given that there will now be lots of data science certificate students taking this course who will be going into industry, I think this is a useful skill to have.) 6) many other.

Strengths: The course was well-organized, with lots of office hours, notes, excellent feedback, and nicely designed p-sets. 

Weaknesses: Perhaps it could be made more intensive - I often found my engagement lagging.
The posted videos allow students to learn at our own pace and is very convenient for reviewing, however, it does make the class a little less engaging.
Love this course!!!
very nice that the course was video recorded. JDRS has great lecture notes in R markdown that explain everything he's doing in class and are very helpful when doing the homework

The course content is offered flexibly online and in class. There is also a lot of help available from office hours and the course online note. I think such easy availability allows students to access the course content and synthesize the materials as their own pace. However, since it's too flexible, I think it's easy for students not to pay attention and only finishing the homework without retaining the material.
There were always office hours with Ta's completely willing to help. The support was awesome. I think it could be improved by having a bit more time for each Pset, but it always worked out fine!
Great course. Taught very well.
Strengths: Lots of material, coding assignments, statistical learning, VIDEO RECORDING OF THE COURSE (a huge plus), team that worked endlessly to grade and provide feedback, application of knowledge

Strengths: The course is live streamed, which is extremely nice. There are lots and lots of office hours, and all of the Gas are extremely helpful, which is terrific. JDRS (professor), is absolutely hilarious, and is engaging and interesting.
Weaknesses: More often than not, learning code is extremely tedious and not very entertaining. This, however, is not a weakness of the class, but instead is simply how learning code is.

The datasets used were really clean. While I appreciated this in the moment, the final project was much harder, and it showed me that while I can run these tests, it doesn't mean much if I can't apply it to a quality dataset. I think this should be emphasized more. I took S&DS 363 concurrently and found that my greatest limiting factor was not the statistics or the multivariate tests, but the data cleaning.

Strengths -- weekly HWs were a useful exercise in engaging with the material; online video lectures were convenient and should definitely be kept as an option for students. The Canvas page was extremely well organized, and all of the resources (code used last in class #, Piazza, office hours) are all great! 

Weaknesses - JDRS' lecturing style was a bit scattered, and it made it difficult to digest some of the statistics concepts. I feel like i came out of this course being very familiar with R, but not so much with actual statistics concepts. The teaching should focus on explicitly outlining "when you can use" this statistical concept more.

Strength: Lecture notes/code were very well-organized and helped facilitate an understanding of the material.

Weakness: Perhaps the homework could have more questions that require statistical thinking beyond repurposing the related code in the lecture materials.

Strengths: JDRS is a really funny lecturer. The lectures are also recorded, so if you don't want to go to lecture, you can always stream them live or watch them at a later time. The class is also very organized. JDRS does a wonderful job of preparing the class notes and code for you to follow along during the lecture.
Weakness: Since it's a big lecture class, it can sometimes feel hard to be really engaged with the material. The exams are all take-home and open note, which is nice. However, I feel like that does detract away from really internalizing the content that we learn.

Strength - breadth 
Weakness - accountability (didn't go to class)
As much as I loved the online format, students would be a lot more engaged if it was in person
The strength is getting to know R and the weakness is that you dont really learn any statistics.
the setup of the course is somewhat unfair, since some people collaborate heavily on assignments while others dont.

Video recording was super nice. Course was super well organized under JDRS

Weaknesses: This class is way toooooo easy, so the grade boundaries are really narrow. It's pretty annoying when the distinguishing factor between an A or A- boils down to whether your title on a graph is too long. Also, the grading isn't quite standardized across TAs. Also the problem with this class being too easy is you walk away feeling as if you learned nothing, and tbh you probably did learn nothing. This class does work well with S&DS 242 though.
Great lectures and rmd files. Homework was sometimes inconsistent in grading

The strengths of this course are that it does a great job of teaching R (and of teaching us how we can keep learning, outside of the class) and that the assignments are all low-stakes and straightforward enough that I could learn without worrying about the grade (this is ESPECIALLY true of the exams, which are take-home and open-notes). It's also great that there are many office hours, since coding can be hard at times. Finally, I really enjoyed building on what I learned in AP Statistics, both in that I learned new statistical techniques and that I got to practice using the techniques on real, "messy" data rather than the clean data of AP Stats.

The main weakness of this course is a lack of statistical theory. I think the amount that we learn given the time constraints is perfect, and I love that the professor gives us links that let us learn more theory on our own if we want, but it's hard to replace hardcore, in-the-weeds theory. I say this less as a message to the professor, since I think he already handles this perfectly, and more as a note to students considering this class who strongly prefer theory over practicality.
you could take the class and not have to go to lectures because everything is online and can be rewatched whenever

This is a great course--professor JDRS is amazing and knows this subject really well. He makes the coding really easy to understand and also makes the lectures super interesting to watch/attend. The ULA's are overall really organized and the assignments are interesting and sufficiently rigorous.

Strength: R, manageable and consistent workload, JDRS charisma
Weakness: statistical intuition (add more to psets)
Fabulous. Learn a ton at your own pace in a low pressure environment. JDRS just wants you to learn, and he makes that happen.

This class is not very god at teaching the logic behind coding, as most of what we did was copy and pasting the code that JDRS gave us. I wish we could have more problem sets where we actually had to understand the logic behind what we were doing, and perhaps reducing the complexity of material as a result.

The online format is super convenient and beneficial because you can watch the lecture when and wherever you want to. JDRS is an amazing instructor. He provides the most helpful notes of any STEM class I've ever taken. The ULA's for this course were also very friendly and helpful at office hours.
Very streamlined course, I felt like I learned a lot about R, and it was actually pretty fun which I was not expecting of an intro stats course.
The course was well organized with clear expectations. It was a great balance of work and intellectual challenge to guidance from the professor and manageable psets and tests.

Strengths: well organized, JDRS is a great lecturer who is amazing at engaging his students, problem sets/exams are straightforward

Weaknesses: none really, unless you would rather have in-class assignments/exams

This course was very well-structured as an introduction to r that was accessible to all students. The format of online lectures, psets, take home exams and a group project meant that students could get help with their coding and properly learn the material. There were plenty of office hours and Professor Reuning-Scherer was very accessible and patient to help all students so this format worked perfectly well to encourage non-STEM and non-data science majors to learn some statistical analyses without the pressure of exams and non-collaborative evaluations.

Strengths:  we got so much support, in the lectures were great to watch outside of class. I just love how well organized it was, and how fun it was to learn new things. 

Weaknesses:  not really any. It was a great and an intimidating way to get interested in data science

Strengths are that the class is very practical and does a good job providing a base in R. The weakness is definitely that the grading is highly variable and depending on your grader, you could be getting an obscene number of points off for tiny things.
Great course. I learned a lot in a flexible environment.

The biggest strength was that it was recorded and posted online, which was great because I was able to revisit lectures, pause the lectures, and occasionally watch them on double speed. No noted weaknesses.
This was one of the best courses I have taken at Yale. Well structured and an excellent lecturer.

Very well structured - both the lecture and the HW. Very good professor and TF support. Many students used the video recordings, which were nice to have, but often-mostly-empty large lecture hall was sometimes a strange setting for the course.

strengths: the freedom to watch the class live stream (which is great because the classroom is rather far and sometimes you do want to revisit/ speed things up as you follow along); great lecture notes and sample codes (very nicely presented, too); awesome teaching staff (a huge company) and office hours almost 24/7 (plus Piazza); an enthusiastic and dedicated instructor (JDRS is GREAT).
weakness: the course material has way too little theory and especially towards the end of the semester you could feel disoriented as to what exactly is the tool that you're learning is for. It does seem like you should take intro stats at Yale before attempting this class, or at least get really good at high school/ AP stats. The class size is also a bit too large.
super well organized! honestly can't think of any weaknesses

Strengths: JDRS, and the amount of time he puts into developing curriculum, helping students during office hours, etc. I think another big strenght of the course is the ULAs. This is SUCH a great class because it makes R accessible to everyone.

Strength: lectures were video recorded and R file available online, so it was very easy to follow along online. Weakness: perhaps a bit too easy to follow along online. Psets follow the lectures almost exactly so it was largely following along with the lecture code. Learned a lot, but I'm not sure how deep it sunk in.

I liked that the lectures were recorded online so I didnt have to go to class. The lecture notes were posted so eventually I was able to learn the material through the notes without even needing to watch the recorded lectures, which made it even better and more on my own time. I like how this course was structured, as having a pretty easy stats course allows students with little free time in their schedule to get adequately introduced to stats. The class was also very organized.

Strengths: Video lectures, amazing teacher, very instructive assignments, take-home midterms, fun final project, large support structure of TAs.
Weakness: Usually at 9am, flexible structure of the course put the burden of time management completely on the student (which is not really a weakness unless time management is a weakness for the particular student).
The strengths were definitely the applied programming skills. I would encourage more statistics and assignments that are less about attention to detail and more difficult.

Problem sets were super helpful - great way to actually implement what we'd been learning in class and try our hand at coding in R. 
Lectures moved pretty quickly, which was good and bad. The biggest victim of this was the statistical theory - I came out of the class feeling like I had a solid understanding of how to run each of the tests, but not of what the tests actually told us or how they worked.
JDRS makes it accessible and has lots of notes readily available. Very strong class, not many critiques beyond it being a 9am far up on Science Hill.

Strengths - flexibility! 
weaknesses - also flexibility; depends on the person and your preferences; it was nice to be able to watch lectures whenever convenient, but it also piled up.

This course does a really good job of forcing students to practice using different functions both inside and outside of the classroom, and the emphasis on hands on learning allows students to complete the course feeling like they have basic coding knowledge in R.
Recorded lectures can be both a blessing and a curse depending on your level of discipline and learning style.
It's a brilliantly taught course.

Strengths: breadth and flexibility of the class
Weakness: disparity of grading across TFs

Professor Reuning-Scherer is an amazing lecturer. He knows how to weave the course material together in an intriguing way. He really makes statistics come to life and interesting to all. However, sometimes it is easy to finish the homework and quizzes without really diving into the subject.

strength: putting it online so that we don't sleep through the 9 am walk to kroon hall, piazza, lots of office hours, great use of canvas platform

weakness: lack of engagement/ deep understanding of underlying stats (but that's mostly the student's fault for not being interested enough to look deeper)
Great class, no complaints.
JDRS was a great lecturer - he was clear, confident and concise. His lectures were easy to follow and I loved how they were recorded so I could learn at my own speed. Psets and exams were fair.
Not 9:00 AM! Very well structured
Brilliant professor, could be graded faster?
The course is very well suited for teaching R, but could be improved by focusing more on the actual statistics behind the tests we are conducting.
Strengths: organization, professor, the material is interesting, course not too difficult
I loved the live-streamed lectures paired with lots of office hours. I think this course organization is perfect for modern learning.
Course is very organized with lots of helpful office hours.
The livestream of the lecture was great because it gave me flexibility in how I learned the class material. Office hours were also very helpful for the weekly assignments.

Strengths: lectures are recorded! Psets are very straightforward! Prof and the TAs are very helpful! Exams are easy! 
Weaknesses: none really

JDRS is good at what he does in this course - which is teach students how to use R. Some of the psets were a lot of copy+paste (with only minor changes), so I think more challenging problem sets could have been a positive improvement for the course.

strength: good homework for practicing
weakness: sometimes things were taught too fast

The fact that the course is recorded (with Jonathan) helped a lot throughout the semester, as I could easily review material that the professor went over. However, the assignments often could be completed simply by copying/pasting code from lecture and simply changing a few variable names. This made it easy to complete assignments, but I felt that I did not learn the material as well as I would have if the problem sets presented more of a challenge.

The course goes a little too quickly, however, office hours are extremely helpful. Also, JDRS' teaching style is engaging and the TAs are great at helping with problem sets. The recordings of the classes are AMAZING!!!! Being able to watch the class when it fits your schedule best is a great part of the class.

Amazing lecturer, super entertaining, and super helpful TAs. The one thing I had an issue with was that I didn't really feel like I understand much of what we were doing on a theoretical level, especially in the second half of the semester it was all over my head.

The course is fairly easy as long as you have some stats background. Working together with other people on psets (even if to check code) is helpful. All the lectures are video recorded which can be both a strength and a weakness. I never went to lecture because I just watched the lectures at another time (usually on 1.5 speed) but sometimes I was lazy and got behind on the lectures some weeks.
Having the classes recorded and available online was very helpful, and submitting assignments electronically through canvas worked very well.
The main strength was the multitude of mediums through which we could learn the material. There were in class lectures, online lectures, PDFs, and classmates. I can't identify any weaknesses.
Yes, a great intro to coding in R.

I would recommend this course to a student seeking an introduction to coding and a review of basic statistics. The problem sets are very much manageable and it is not hard to do well on them. This course is not extremely engaging, but provides a good overview of how to use R.
yeah its whatever

Yes, if what you want is a course on R. If you're looking to learn R, this class is wonderful for it. If you're looking to get a better understanding of statistics, look at 220 (where R is an afterthought, whereas in 230, the statistics are the afterthoughts).
Yes, you learn in a less stressful environment

Yes, this course is great if you want to develop practical programming skills for analysis of data tables. It also exposes you to many different graphics and important statistical tests for data analysis.
Yes, i definitely would. Very useful and good overview of how to practically deal with data
Yeah definitely - not to hard and you actually use something useful. JDRS is a great teacher of this stuff too and the TAs are super helpful.
Yes. Take this class.

I would recommend this course to another student, especially if that student were looking for a solid introduction to coding or to utilizing statistical tools on datasets. I wish I would have taken this class earlier in my Yale career!

Yes, it's a good introduction to using R. The theory behind actual statistical methods wasn't explained or used as often, but it's a good course for learning how to use this programming language in an applicable manner.
Absolutely
Yes! Great intro to R and statistical analysis.
Absolutely! If someone wants to learn R, this is an excellent course to get started!
If you want to learn R - this is a great course. If you want to learn more statistics - I would take a different course.
Absolutely. JDRS is an excellent and witty professor that makes you want to engage with the material. Go to lectures if you can! He's truly a performer live, and you learn a lot too!
If you would like to learn how to use R and brush up on statistical techniques, sure. Beware though that this course focuses more on R than the underlying statistics knowledge.
Yes,  I would recommend this course because it is not soul-crushingly difficult but it teaches a lot about R, a very important skill nowadays.
No; learn R on your own and take a more stats focused course

I would recommend this course if you are looking to learn how to do basic coding in R. Even if you feel like your statistics background is weak, you only need to know the very basics of intro stats in order to take this course.

I would recommend this course because it satisfies exactly what it describes itself to be. The course description makes it clear that it's designed for you to learn how to code in R and some intermediate statistical analysis techniques - that is, a review of some you may have covered in intro stats, and an introduction to some that are more advanced. It's also clear how to succeed in this course, and the course is designed so that you can succeed, in both learning, receiving feedback, and getting a good grade. If you're considering an intro/intermediate level statistics or coding class, take this one: NOT S&DS 230, NOT anything CPSC.

If you have no prior coding experience and want a very simple introduction to a useful statistical programming language, then take it. It's the lowest-stress class I've taken here at Yale, mainly because exams are all take-home, and you don't even have to walk to lecture (it's recorded). Final project can be fun if you do it right. Good to tack on as a 5th or 6th and just get the experience.
Yes! Learning R is honestly really empowering.
Yes, if you want to improve your R programming skills, then take this class.
yes! great intro course. great professor. very funny! classes are online so I stopped going to class and immediately regretted it when I would look at the lectures and he was sooooo funny!
Yes! JDRS is incredible
YES! Its fun and light.
Definitely. This class teaches you how to program in R (very useful), and how to clean/analyze lots of different kinds of datasets. Pretty chill STEM, but you still learn a good amount.
If you want to learn a lot about stats, sure.
I would. It is a good course to take to learn to code.

Yes. Cleaning and manipulating data is an essential part of any field. Using R makes this process much faster and if you're somewhat good at it, prettier. This class is a painless way to dip your toes into the endless study of data.

Yes! the midterms were both take home, I never actually went to a class I simply watched all the lectures online, and there is a google calendar of TA times on canvas which occur multiple time a day on every day of the week. I loved the material in this class and if you choose to do so, you can learn a lot and really expand your R programming abilities.

If you are interested in doing data analysis in the future and learning R, then I would recommend this class. Everything is recorded so you don't actually have to go and there are no in-class assessments. Just have to be prepared to make it a priority to go to office hours to get help with psets.
Great introduction to R! The problem sets and take-home exams are super straightforward, and there is a lot of ULA support through office hours and Piazza.
A decent amount of work and the final project is a lot, but you learn a lot as well.
I would recommend this class. It is fun and you learn very practical skills that are applicable to many jobs.
Absolutely, I learned a lot, the class was very well structured, and feedback and help were readily available
Yes! Very good class that teaches you R and statistical techniques.
Yes, I feel like it teaches you important material without being too difficult or time-consuming.

Yale doesn't have another data analysis course, nor does it have another intro to R course, but if you're taking this just to learn R, then I'd strongly just recommend reading and self-teaching using the free online textbook, R for Data Science (https://r4ds.had.co.nz/). Otherwise, yeah, take it, it's not a bad course but there are so many ways this course could be improved.

Yes, definitely! JDRS is a good lecturer and more importantly organized this course very well to make so many resources available to us. You really have the ability to set your own limits learning R, and even if you put a moderate amount of effort in, will come out with many useful skills.
YES! Super useful, low workload, Professor amazing
yes, you learn some good skills and JDRS is a good lecturer. there are also lots of resources available (many TAs and JDRS providing office hours every day of the week)

I would recommend this course. It was time consuming and challenging to get the hang of R, but completely manageable if one is willing to put in the work. Office hours are a must! Professor JDRS is always very kind and helpful.
Great class. Data Science is important in any field so definitely take the class.
Yes. This course teaches statistics and R with plenty of potential applications.

I, 10/10 would recommend this course to most students at Yale. The information is applicable not only to S&DS focused people, but to everyone is every discipline, because data is used everywhere for everything. It teaches you the basics of coding, and overall dataset analysis techniques, with statistical vocabulary that is essential to know in the professional world.

One of the most useful classes I've taken at Yale, super enjoyable to watch, and not too difficult. Definite recommend for anyone in natural or social sciences. I will definitely use this material later in life.
Yes, this course did a great job of providing an introduction to coding in R and how to apply basic statistical tests and get a feel for datasets.

If you're interested in statistics, take it. The course is very practical. You analyze a lot of real-world data sets through R. It's not really a lot of CS if you've been exposed to it before. Oddly enough, there isn't a lot of math involved either.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students who want to gain a basic understanding of R.
No
Yeah, good arts course that gets read out of way but I dont think I learned much
The perfect class to learn R in. Take with JDRS -- he's an incredible educator and professor
I would recommend it as a an interesting and useful QR that isnt too much work.

If you're not quantitative at all, yes.

If you are, beware, this class is so easy for you that you'll learn nothing. And also it's not necessarily an easy A because it's so easy that the grade boundaries are wack.

I would recommend this course. It is relatively chill and attending lectures is entirely optional. That said, you should watch the lectures because JDRS is an entertaining lecturer and the underlying material is very useful.
If you haven't used R or haven't programmed before, this is a gentle and enjoyable intro class.

Absolutely! Though you should take intro stats first. Coding may take some time to get used to, but you do get used to it. The only issue is that you won't get extensive statistical theory training here, but that doesn't necessarily have to be a problem, especially if you're not an S&DS major. In general, this class is a great intro to R and to the usage of stats in the real world.
Yes, especially juniors about to write their senior thesis in the next year
Absolutely! The workload is manageable and the exams are both take-home. The project is not too bad because you get to work in a group of up to four people. Professor JDRS is amazing! Great lecturer!
Yep!
For sure
Yes to learn R, no if they want to learn how to code

Amazing class to follow intro stats. Gives a great overview of data analysis and using R. Would definitely recommend, especially to students not in the Stats major who are looking to get a better understanding of statistical analysis. GO TO OFFICE HOURS!!!! You will learn a lot if you put in the time.

Yes, this is an excellent course! I already knew CS but I believe it is accessible to everyone because of JDRS's great teaching. Being able to clean and manipulate data is a skill I think is useful in many fields.

If you're interested in learning R and want to take a course to see if you like statistics, I would recommend taking 230! It's super helpful to be able to look back over recorded lectures and I think the psets are challenging enough while still being very fair.

Absolutely! Great class to take if you're not sure if you want to take more classes in the S&DS department. Low workload but you still can learn a lot if you make the effort to do so. Highly recommend
I would definitely recommend this course, if it is taught in this format and by Professor Reuning-Scherer.
Yes, absolutely!  It is great for at least a skill development for anyone
very useful course
Would recommend if you need/want to learn R
Yes. This is a great course. I learned a lot about R and data analysis. The workload is extremely manageable.
Yes! Amazing class.
If you are looking for a challenging but completely doable course introducing you to the basis of data analysis with R, you wont find much better than this.
Yes. Good way to learn R and basic stats, reasonable amount of work (PSETs are fairly easy, project gives opportunity to apply new skills).

If you already have a solid background in stats and would like to learn a new language from scratch, or if you're looking to jumpstart your data analytics for a project, this class is perfect for you. It might be a little too easy if you already know how to code.
Yes! Wonderful class if you want to learn the basics of how to work with data!
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT

I would recommend this course to take after high school AP Stats or equivalent non-R course. The class was thorough in explaining how to use R to perform previously learned skills and would be doable for anyone who is coming into this class even after a long break from stats. Very little explanation about coding, so good if you have previous coding experience but perhaps a big of a sharp jump for someone with no coding experience. Lectures are video recorded and lecture R files are available online so don't let the 9am time slot scare you away. JRS is a great instructor for this course.

This class is so easy and requires no time. The lectures are recorded but you dont even need to watch them  you can just have the posted lecture notes open as you do the pset and its a lot of easy copy and pasting. The take home midterms and the final are of that caliber as well  very easy. You do get exposure to a bunch of statistical analysis methods which is good. Great 5th class option to get introduced to some stats without wanting to put in/having a lot of time to dedicate to it.

Absolutely! Most high-end jobs of today will require direct involvement with or at least an understanding of data analysis. This course will give you all the tools you need to dive into that world, and will do so in a way that doesn't put too much burden on your schedule (so long as you don't fall behind in watching the lectures).
Absolutely. It is a must take regardless of your major.

Great class if you're trying to learn R - very low workload but you come out of it feeling comfortable with the program. Also was very well organized in terms of lectures (live-streamed, files posted), office hours, and resources. Not a great introduction to statistics - take an intro class first if you want to actually understand the tests that you're running.
Absolutely. Incredible introductory class and super important skill to have.
yes! it is a low stress way to learn R; just make sure to keep up with it
If you are looking to learn R this is a great, chill course to take. Even if you have never coded before, you can do well in this course and feel like you are actually learning week to week.
Absolutely, do not let the coding in R intimidate you! I l had no coding experience and did just fine.
Absolutely -- low stress, high Reward Class
I would recommend to anyone seeking further exploration in statistics, especially non-majors.
Yes, especially to those who have not tried programming before and with basic knowledge of statistics.
It doesn't hurt to learn a data analysis language and R is the most useful one so yes.
Yes, great class.

I would recommend this course to another student. JDRS is an incredible professor who is very clear and thorough with his teaching. Also, the problem sets and midterms are similar to what is shown in class with a few deviations. The only problem I had was keeping up with the lecture videos as the semester went on, which made the problem sets and midterms more difficult than they needed to be. Take the class if you're willing to go to lecture/keep up with the recordings in order to get the best understanding of the course.
Yes! A great intro class if you want to learn r
Yes! A great introduction to R.
Yes! A fun class. Super chill. You learn coding. Make sure you have some coding background or it might be a little hard.
Definitely. Loved the material and the prof, gained a valuable skill in coding R and statistical analysis
I would recommend this course to anyone at Yale. Having a knowledge of statistics can be very beneficial to anyone, especially if you can put that knowledge to work.
Absolutely. To anyone interested in a basic overview of applied statistics or in learning how to use R.
Yes, if you're already familiar with basic statistics topics (t-tests, variability, correlation, etc).

This course is great if you want an intro-level course about statistical coding using R. If you took an stats course before in high school or in college, JDRS does a great job of giving a refresher on statistics through the lectures and assignments. The workload of this class isn't too heavy and I still felt like I learned a lot.
Yes! It's a good data analysis class that's fairly easy and leaves with you some important skills. JDRS is also amazing, we love him!!

Yes, but only after taking a course in basic statistical theory. Students who take this course as their first stats class (or who don't remember stats from high school) will not understand the processes behind why we do what we do, and the class will be much harder for them as a result. This class can be almost a gut if you treat it like one, but how much you learn (or remember learning) will be proportionate to how much effort you put in.
yes. Good change to pick up not only the theoretical statistic but also the R programming.

I would recommend this course to any student that wants to learn how to program in R. The language is important in data analysis and visualization and would be a valuable asset to any researcher's toolkit.
Yes!!! Coding R is very useful for many fields, especially economics which is a very popular major. Again, the course was engaging and overall I found data analysis fascinating.

It depends on what you want from data exploration. From what I've heard, if you want more statistical knowledge and understanding of the statistical methods beyond the code, 220 is the home for you. However, if you're more interested in learning code and getting a more in-depth look at R programming, then stat 230 is the right place for you.
Yes if you want to get an introduction into using R.

If you want to learn some coding through the R language and already have some stats background, then this is a pretty good low-workload class. I learned a good amount of R even though the psets only took maybe 4-5 hours a week on average.
Yes
Yes
Yes. It was a great advanced introduction to coding, data analysis, and statistics.
